@Chemomancer thanks for clearing that up. :)

They wouldn't have been allowed to. While it is possible to bankroll (pay for) a lawsuit on behalf of another person - no individual or company can sue on another person's behalf. The person initiating a lawsuit *must* be the aggrieved party - meaning the only one who could sue The Sun on Johnny Depp's behalf was... Johnny Depp. The only exception being, of course, if Depp had handed anyone else power of attorney.

With that said, they certainly shouldn't have fired him. While it's certainly a good thing that corrupt womanizers in Hollywood are actually being addressed - I've been saying since day one that this cultural expectation of "Allegation = Fire them" was an expectation that was ripe for abuse. A company can choose to hire or fire as they see fit of course - but that doesn't mean their decision to hire or fire cannot be determined to be unethical. It's my opinion that these individuals should only be fired should their case come to a *conviction*, which very clearly wasn't the case here... and I hold Disney in much disdain for jumping on this bandwagon.

Fortunately... Disney has issued an apology, and even re-hired him. It seems they realize their mistake.
